Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multiscale Modeling and Experimental Study of Blood Cell Interactions with Application to Functionalized Leukocytes Killing Cancer Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
More than 90% of cancer-related deaths are caused by cancer metastasis, the spread of a cancer. In many cases, cancer cells escape from the primary tumor and enter vasculature to form circulating tumor cells (CTCs). CTCs inside blood vessels are able to adhere to vessel walls, and then migrate into tissues, eventually forming micro-metastases. Recently, it was found that when nano-particles coated with certain types of ligands and receptors on their surfaces were injected into the blood, these particles can bind to CTCs and subsequently trigger death of CTCs in the blood. The project concerns using integrated mathematical/computational modeling and experiments to understand quantitatively how this binding process occurs and to identify the roles that ligand-receptor binding and cell-cell interactions play during this process. Results from the project will shed light on designing new nano-particle medical processes for the treatment of cancer metastasis and broadly extend the knowledge of blood cell dynamics. The results are of practical importance in many applications in both bio-engineering and medical communities. The research will also provide interdisciplinary training for students.

By combining modeling, simulation and experiments, this project addresses a key biological question of importance to understanding cancer metastasis. What are the key factors that contribute to improving the efficiency of coated nano particles for triggering the death of circulating cancer cells within the vascular system? New three-dimensional multi-scale models will be developed for this study. In this context, a novel sub-model representing cell membrane mechanics, a fluid-structure interaction simulation method and a stochastic ligand-receptor bond bind/unbinding sub-model will be developed and coupled. Atomic force microscopy and micro-fluidic experiments at three spatial scales will be designed for model validation and verifying simulation predictions. The transformative strategy of coupling calibrated multi-scale simulations with experiments will enable testing of novel hypothesized mechanisms by which certain coatings of liposomes kill flowing tumor cells. These goals will be achieved by using an iterative procedure involving development of sub-models, running experiments to validate the sub-models, and then running predictive simulations and designing new experiments for verification of these predictions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project concerns developing multiscale predictive models for studying problems involving blood cells, other types of biological cells and cell-cell, cell-environment (ECM) interactions. The award was also used to partially support development of high-order accurate and efficient numerical schemes for simulation study of applications in biology, physics and engineering. This grant was used to partially support one graduate student who is now in the third year’s PhD study and works on developing multiscale complex fluid models for hydro-gel biomaterials, and applying the model to studying cancer cell aggregation and blood clot formation. Seven peer-reviewed journal papers describing research results were published in top journals in different fields during the grant period, and many invited talks were given to publicize these results.

Several multiscale models developed under the grant support was applied to studying blood clot formation, deformation and embolization and epi-cell growth in packed tissue, respectively. Blood clot is life-threatening and is often accompanied with cancer complication. Therefore, understanding factors mediating its formation and its mechanical properties leading to blood clot embolization and breakage will potentially help find new treatment for blood clot related diseases. The Epi-Scale model was applied to studying tumor cell progression. Under the partial support of this award, we also developed several high-order accurate and efficient numerical schemes for simulating applications in astrophysics and coastal engineering and atmospheric modeling.  

Specifically, in terms of model and simulation methodology development, we developed various multiscale predictive models at different spatio-temporal scales for biological applications. Major project outcomes related to this aspect include:

1) a novel thermodynamically consistent multi-phase complex fluid model for studying mechanical stability of hydro-gel.  Using this model, we investigated how elasticity of the blood clot changes pressure inside the blood clot, which contributes to blood clot contraction. For the blood clot simulation, the model takes into account interactions between the main blood clot components, including fibrin, highly and partially activated platelets, liquid plasma, as well as elastic and viscous properties of the clot components.  Our simulation results suggest that various shear rates induce changes in clot size via two mechanisms, namely (i) relative formation and breakage of weak bonds between individual platelets and the surface of the clot, and (ii) tearing pieces off the clot (embolization). The latter mechanism is about five times more effective in modulating the size of a matured arteriolar clot.

2) a stochastic kinetics model for cell membrane receptor and ECM binding. Using this model, we revealed that platelet receptor αIIbβ3 has a higher probability of forming mechanically stable interactions with p-fibrin than with fibrinogen. Targeting platelet binding to p-fibrin, rather than platelet aggregation, may be a way to increase the therapeutic indices of anti-platelet agents.

3) a mechanistic fibrin network model for simulating fibrin network deformation under external load caused by flow or other factors. Our simulation results show that the nascent cohesive crisscrossing of fibers in stretched fibrin networks comprise an underappreciated important structural mechanism, underlying local strain-stiffening of individual fibers as well as global stiffening of the entire network. 4) a GPU-based cell model (Epi-Scale) for studying mitotic rounding during cell division and tissue development. An understanding of how perturbed mechanical properties impact mitotic rounding has important potential implications on, amongst others, how tumors progressively become more genetically unstable due to increased chromosomal aneuploidy and more aggressive.

We also developed many efficient, high-order accurate simulation methods for simulation study of problems in biology, biophysics and physics. These methods include: 1) an energy-stable numerical scheme for solving a class of coupled Navier-Stokes and Cahn-Hilliard equations. These equations commonly occur in complex fluid models in biology and physics. We used this numerical method to simulate blood clot deformation and embolization. 2) GPU simulation algorithm for Epi-Scale model for massively parallel simulation. 3) High-order accurate numerical schemes for applications in astrophysics and coastal engineering and atmospheric modeling. These include central discontinuous Galerkin (DG) and central finite volume schemes for MHD simulations and well-balanced DG scheme for simulating shallow water equations on unstructured grids.

This award also provided graduate student training and professional opportunity.  In addition to renovate the advanced scientific computing course for senior undergraduate students and graduate students in science and engineering, I also introduce a graduate level topics course which will be started to offering in Spring 2020. This topics course will cover various model development methods and numerical schemes for solving model equations.
